awd_titl_txt: Second International Congress of Sustainability Science and Engineering: Where Science and Engineering Meet the Needs of Society
awd_abstract_narration:
PI:  Yinlun Huang
Proposal Number:  1048263 
Institution:  Wayne State University
Title:  Second International Congress of Sustainability Science and Engineering: Where Science and Engineering Meet the Needs of Society

Depletion of nonrenewable resources, forests, and stratospheric ozone, pollution of air, water, and soil, global warming, scarcity of water for drinking and agriculture, excessive population growth, etc., are among the major challenges to global society. Naturally, how to ensure engineering sustainability becomes a focal point in balancing economic, environmental and social developments today. Industrial efforts have been increasingly significant on developing green materials and products, designing sustainable systems, improving energy and material use efficiency, ensuring business sustainability, etc. In parallel, a large number of academic researchers in different disciplines of engineering, natural and social sciences have been conducting various types of research on sustainability, aiming at developing sound theories, comprehensive assessment and systematic analysis and design methodologies, powerful decision support tools, etc.
To address much broader issues of sustainability science and engineering, facilitate discussions on scientific and technological development, and share research and practice experiences in industrial sustainability, a group of scientists, educators, and engineers, and governmental officers is organizing The Second International Congress on Sustainability Science and Engineering: Where Science and Engineered Technologies Meet the Needs of Society. The congress will be held in Tucson, Arizona, January 9-13, 2011.

This second congress is designed to provide a platform for researchers in engineering, physical and ecological sciences, economics, and social sciences and industrial practitioners from different continents of the world to exchange emerging ideas about ways and means of protecting the environment and its resources so that humans can achieve sustained economic growth and societal benefits throughout generations. While broad topics in sustainability are to be covered, this congress will focus on the sustainability issues particularly important to the western U.S., such as water, renewable (solar) energy, high-tech manufacturing, land use/ecosystems, etc. The congress should help bridge the gap between research and development, strengthening the linkage between industries and academia, and explore opportunities for international collaboration in the proposed technical areas.

This congress will attract many industrial leaders and top academic researchers from all over the world for participation. This project is for supporting the US academic researchers, educators and students to attend the conference. This will help them learn the cutting-age research in the field of sustainability, share their experience with the world-class leaders and other colleagues, and identify international collaboration opportunities in sustainable engineering research and education. Junior faculty members, undergraduate and graduate students, especially those minorities underrepresented in science and engineering, will be encouraged to participate in the congress. This congress will lead to a publication of a volume in sustainability science and engineering. It is envisioned that this event will be the prelude for active international collaboration on sustainable engineering.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Depletion of nonrenewable resources, forests, and stratospheric ozone, pollution of air, water, and soil, global warming, scarcity of water for drinking and agriculture, excessive population growth, etc., are among the major challenges to global society.  Naturally, how to ensure engineering sustainability becomes a focal point in balancing economic, environmental and social developments today.  Industrial efforts have been increasingly significant on developing green materials and products, designing sustainable systems, improving energy and material use efficiency, ensuring business sustainability, etc.  In parallel, a large number of academic researchers in different disciplines of engineering, natural and social sciences have been conducting various types of research on sustainability, aiming at developing sound theories, comprehensive assessment and systematic analysis and design methodologies, powerful decision support tools, etc. 

To address much broader issues of sustainability science and engineering, facilitate discussions on scientific and technological development, and share research and practice experiences in industrial sustainability, a group of scientists, educators, and engineers, and governmental officers organized The Second International Congress on Sustainability Science and Engineering: Where Science and Engineered Technologies Meet the Needs of Society.  The congress was held in Tucson, Arizona, January 9-13, 2011.

 This second congress was designed to provide a platform for researchers in engineering, physical and ecological sciences, economics, and social sciences and industrial practitioners from different continents of the world to exchange emerging ideas about ways and means of protecting the environment and its resources so that humans can achieve sustained economic growth and societal benefits throughout generations.  While broad topics in sustainability are to be covered, this congress will focus on the sustainability issues particularly important to the western U.S., such as water, renewable (solar) energy, high-tech manufacturing, land use/ecosystems, etc.  The congress should help bridge the gap between research and development, strengthening the linkage between industries and academia, and explore opportunities for international collaboration in the proposed technical areas. 

National Science Foundation and EPA were the main sponsors of the conference.  It was co-sponsored by 14 organizations (NIST, U. of Arizona (College of Engineering and Water Sustainability Program), U. of Kentucky, U. of Cincinnati (Wanger Institute for Sustainable Energy Research), Pegasus Technical Services, Toyota, Trojan UV, Rochester Institute of Technology (Golisano Institute for Sustainability), APT Water, Dionex Corp., Dow Chemical, Malcolm Pirnie Corp., and AIChE (Institute for Sustainability and Sustainable Engineering Forum), and partnered with three professional societies (IEEE, ACS Green Chemistry Institute), and ASME. 

The Congress was co-chaired by Dr. Subhas Sikdar of EPA and Dr. Glenn Schrader of University of Arizona.  The PI Huang served on the Steering Committee and was a session chair for the Congress.    The congress attracted over 325 attendees from 19 Countries (Australia, Belgium, Brazil, Canada, China, Croatia, Denmark, France, Germany, Hungary, Ireland, Japan, Netherlands, New Zealand, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, United Kingdom, and U.S.).  A total of 15 government agencies, 70 commercial companies, and 59 academic institutions participated.  Ninety four speakers gave oral presentations.  The congress also organized student poster paper competition.  Two graduate students and two undergraduate students were selected as the winners.

The main purpose of the congress was the Exploration of the Technical Approaches for Attaining Sustainability.  The Congress provided a unique forum for the researchers, scientists, and practitioners from different continents to assess and critique the current status of the challenging field and to identify future directions of research and development in sustainability science and engineering.  The plenary speakers of the congress included the following distinguished U.S. industrial leaders and Governmental Agency Officers: A. Hecht of EPA, D. Welch of American Electric Power, T. Kotanchek of Dow Chemical, J. B. Clare of URS Corp., D. Parekh of United Technologies, and P. Bryan of DOE, and T. Peterson of NSF.  The congress was composed of the following 16 oral sessions plus two poster session, covering the following technical areas: Plenary Session, Session 1: Sustainable Natural Resource Development, Session 2: Sustainable Manufacturing, Session 3: Sustainable Materials, Processing and Product Design, Session 4.  Sustainability Through Green Chemistry and Engineering, Session 5: Product Life Cycle Assessment: Recycle/Reuses/Remanufacturing, Session 6: Sustainable Supply Chain, Session 7: Metrics for Sustainability, Session 8: Standards and Protocols, Session 9: Sustainable Built Environment, Session 10: Non-fossil Fuels for Transportation, Session 11: Sustainable Water Management, Session 12: Teaching and Educational Programs in Sustainability, Session 13: Advances in Low Carbon Power Generation, Session 14: Sustainable Water Technologies, Session 15: Sustainable Ecosystems Engineering, and Poster Session I-II (General and Student Posters).

The congress was the 2nd of this kind held in the U.S.  The presentations by the U.S. participants were well received by all the conference attendees.  The congress covered near all the challenging topics in the field of sustainability science and engineering.  It also helped the US delegates identify international collaboration opportunities in the research and education of sustainability science and engineering. 


Last Modified: 09/05/2011
Modified by: Yinlun Huang
